author: Michael Mayer
description: This middleware is part of a set of middleware to handle CSRF. This one is used for accepting CSRF tokens sent by HTTP headers.

author: Michael Mayer
description: This middleware is part of a set of middleware to handle CSRF. This one is used for whitelisting certain HTTP methods.

author: Michael Mayer
description: This middleware is part of a set of middleware to handle CSRF. This one is used for accepting CSRF tokens sent by the request bodies, e.g. `POST`.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Generates a message using the [Apache's Access Log format](https://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.4/logs.html#accesslog). This middleware requires a [PSR-3](http://www.php-fig.org/psr/psr-3/) compliant logger.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Generates a message using the [Apache's Access Log format](https://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.4/logs.html#accesslog). This middleware requires a [PSR-3](http://www.php-fig.org/psr/psr-3/) compliant logger.

author: Glen Eggleton
description: Provides an ACL repository and middleware unsing `Zend/Permissions/ACL` library. It inspects the current route and compares it to the list ot accessible resources in a middleware. Returns a `401` is a user is not allowed.

author: BitExpert AG team
description: Provides an [ADR](http://pmjones.io/adr/) middleware. To configure the middleware you need provide an array of `\bitExpert\Adroit\Action\Resolver\ActionResolver`, an array of `\bitExpert\Adroit\Responder\Resolver\ResponderResolver` and a action request attribute telling adroit where to look for the action identifier.

author: Leandro Silva
description: Returns a formatted json in case of error. It's inspired on the [ApiProblem](https://github.com/zfcampus/zf-api-problem) library, but with fewer dependencies.

author: Vassilis Kanellopoulos
description: A middleware to serve assets from non public directories.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Provides the ability to route middleware specific attributes into regular request attributes. It can receive a configuration array specifying how to manage the mapping.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Allows the use of [Aura Router](https://github.com/auraphp/Aura.Router) as a middleware. It needs an Aura `RouterContainer` as dependency.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Allows the use of [Aura Router](https://github.com/auraphp/Aura.Router) as a middleware. It needs an Aura `RouterContainer` as dependency.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Creates a new [Aura Session](https://github.com/auraphp/Aura.Session) instance with the request. It nees an Aura `SessionFactory` as dependency.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Creates a new [Aura Session](https://github.com/auraphp/Aura.Session) instance with the request. It nees an Aura `SessionFactory` as dependency.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Removes the prefix from the uri path of the request. This is useful to combine with routers if the root of the website is in a subdirectory. For example, if the root of your website is `/web/public`, a request with the uri `/web/public/post/34` will be converted to `/post/34`. You can provide the prefix to remove or let the middleware autodetect it. In the router you can retrieve the prefix removed or a callable to generate more urls with the base path.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Removes the prefix from the uri path of the request. This is useful to combine with routers if the root of the website is in a subdirectory. For example, if the root of your website is `/web/public`, a request with the uri `/web/public/post/34` will be converted to `/post/34`. You can provide the prefix to remove or let the middleware autodetect it. In the router you can retrieve the prefix removed or a callable to generate more urls with the base path.

author: Leandro Silva
description: Removes the prefix from the uri path of the request.

author: Mateusz Tymek
description: Detects base URL of a web application. It is useful when you need your app to be served from a subdirectory.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Implements [basic Http authentication](http://php.net/manual/en/features.http-auth.php). It needs to be configured with an array with all users and passwords.

author: Witold Wasiczko
description: Provides the possibility to prevent your site from being indexed by search engines, adding a `X-Robots-Tag` header with `noindex, nofollow` value and a `robots.txt` file with `Disallow: /` body.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Blocks requests with a spam referral using the [piwik/referrer-spam-blacklist](https://github.com/piwik/referrer-spam-blacklist) list.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Saves the response headers in cache and returns a `304` response (`Not modified`) if the request is cached. It also adds `Cache-Control` and `Last-Modified` headers to the response. You need a cache library compatible with [PSR-6](www.php-fig.org/psr/psr-6). It requires also [micheh/psr7-cache](https://github.com/micheh/psr7-cache).

author: Oscar Otero
description: Saves the response headers in a [PSR-6](http://www.php-fig.org/psr/psr-6/) cache pool and returns `304` responses (`Not modified`) if the response is still valid. This approach saves server resources and bandwidth because the body is returned empty. It is recomended to combine this middleware with [Expires](http://www.php-middleworld.com/detail/expires-psr-15) to set the lifetime of the responses.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Adds the response headers for cache prevention using [micheh/psr7-cache](https://github.com/micheh/psr7-cache). Useful in development environment.

author: Oscar Otero
description: A simple way to create middlewares using callables with the same signature of a single pass middleware.

author: Andreas Heigl
description: Implements the Clacks-Header as per [http://www.gnuterrypratchett.com](http://www.gnuterrypratchett.com).

author: Oscar Otero
shortDescription: Middleware to detect the client ip(s)
description: Tries to detect the ip(s) of the client using the request `Forwarded`, `Forwarded-For`, `Client-Ip`, `X-Forwarded`, `X-Forwarded-For`, `X-Cluster-Client-Ip` headers.

author: Oscar Otero
shortDescription: Middleware to detect the client ip(s)
description: Tries to detect the ip(s) of the client using the request `Forwarded`, `Forwarded-For`, `Client-Ip`, `X-Forwarded`, `X-Forwarded-For`, `X-Cluster-Client-Ip` headers.

author: Prooph team
description: Part of he Prooph ecosystem. Dispatches the message data to the command bus system. The middleware needs a request attribute to create the appropriare message object.

author: Diego Drigani
description: Content Validation is a middleware for automating validation of incoming input using [Zend InputFilter](https://zendframework.github.io/zend-inputfilter/).

author: Oscar Otero
description: It uses [neomerx/cors-psr7](https://github.com/neomerx/cors-psr7) to manage CORS request. It is configurable through an Neomerx `SettingsStrategyInterface` instance.

author: Oscar Otero
description: It uses [neomerx/cors-psr7](https://github.com/neomerx/cors-psr7) to manage CORS request. It is configurable through an Neomerx `SettingsStrategyInterface` instance.

author: Aurimas Niekis
description: It uses [neomerx/cors-psr7](https://github.com/neomerx/cors-psr7) to manage CORS request. It is configurable through an Neomerx `SettingsStrategyInterface` instance.

author: Mika Tuupola
description: This middleware implements Cross-origin resource sharing. Internally the middleware uses [neomerx/cors-psr7](https://github.com/neomerx/cors-psr7) library for heavy lifting.

author: Oscar Otero
description: It uses the [paragonie/csp-builder](https://github.com/paragonie/csp-builder) library to add the `Content-Security-Policy` header to the response. It is configurable through an array of policies.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Middleware to add the `Content-Security-Policy` header to the response using [paragonie/csp-builder](https://github.com/paragonie/csp-builder) library. It can also handle the CSP error reports using a [PSR-3](http://www.php-fig.org/psr/psr-3/) implementation.

author: Oscar Otero
shortDescription: Cross site request forgery protection middleware
description: To add a protection layer agains CSRF (Cross Site Request Forgery). The middleware injects a hidden input with a token in all `POST` forms and them check whether the token is valid or not. Use `->autoInsert()` to insert automatically the token or, if you prefer, use the generator callable.

author: Marco Pivetta
shortDescription: Cross site request forgery protection middleware using JWT tokens
description: Enables CSRF (Cross Site Request Forgery) protection using JWT tokens, which can be verified, signed and have a specific lifetime on their own.

author: Slim Team
shortDescription: Cross site request forgery protection middleware
description: CSRF (Cross Site Request Forgery) protection applied to all unsagfe HTTP requests (POST, PUT, DELETE, PATCH).

author: Oscar Otero
description: Inserts the [PHP debug bar](http://phpdebugbar.com/) in the Html body, provinding helpful informations about the Http call. This middleware requires `Middleware::formatNegotiator` to be executed before, to insert the debug bar on in Html responses.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Inserts the [PHP debug bar](http://phpdebugbar.com/) in the Html body, provinding helpful informations about the Http call.

author: Witold Wasiczko
description: Provides the possibility to attach the [PHP debug bar](http://phpdebugbar.com/) to your response, both with html or non-html contexts.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Delays the response to simulate slow bandwidth in local environments. You can use a number or an array to generate random values in seconds.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Uses [Mobile-Detect](https://github.com/serbanghita/Mobile-Detect) to detect whether the request was performed by a mobile device.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Implements the [digest Http authentication](http://php.net/manual/en/features.http-auth.php). It needs to be configured with an array with users and passwords.

author: Woody Gilk
shortDescription: An HTTP Interop compatible middleware dispatcher
description: An HTTP Interop compatible middleware dispatcher in [Equip](https://equipframework.readthedocs.io/). Attempts to be [PSR-1](www.php-fig.org/psr/psr-1), [PSR-2](www.php-fig.org/psr/psr-2), [PSR-4](www.php-fig.org/psr/psr-4), [PSR-7](www.php-fig.org/psr/psr-6), and [PSR-15](https://github.com/php-fig/fig-standards/tree/master/proposed/http-middleware) compliant.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Middleware to compress the response body to `Deflate` format using [gzdeflate](http://php.net/manual/en/function.gzdeflate.php) and add the `Content-Encoding: deflate` header.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Middleware to compress the response body to `Gzip` format using [gzencode](http://php.net/manual/en/function.gzencode.php) and add the `Content-Encoding: gzip` header.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Uses [willdurand/Negotiation](https://github.com/willdurand/Negotiation) to detect and negotiate the encoding type of the document.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Executes an handler if the response returned by the next middleware has an error status code (`400`-`599`). It also catches all the exceptions thrown by the next middleware.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Middleware to execute a handler if the response returned by the next middlewares has any error (status code 400-599) or throws a `Middleware/HttpErrorException`. This package provides the `Middleware/HttpErrorException` that you can use to send context-related data to the error handler. The methods `setContext(array $data)` and `getContext()` methods allows to assign and retrieve the error context data used in the error handler.

author: Prasetyo Wicaksono
description: Error handling middleware. Depends on [flip/whoops](https://github.com/filp/whoops) for error formatting and [psr/log](https://github.com/php-fig/log) for abstraction on logging.

author: Prooph team
description: Part of he Prooph ecosystem. Dispatches the message data to the event bus system. The middleware needs a request attribute to create the appropriare message object.

author: Relay Php team
description: Catches any exceptions that bubble up through the subsequent middleware decorators. It does nothing with the `$request` or `$response`, and passes them directly to `$next` inside a try/catch block. If no exception bubbles up, it returns the `$response` from `$next`. However, if it catches an exception, it returns an entirely new `$response` object with the exception message and an `HTTP 500` status code.

author: Relay Php team
description: Catches any exceptions that bubble up through the subsequent middleware decorators. It does nothing with the `$request` or `$response`, and passes them directly to `$next` inside a try/catch block. If no exception bubbles up, it returns the `$response` from `$next`. However, if it catches an exception, it returns an entirely new `$response` object with the exception message and an `HTTP 500` status code. This is suitable for use in evironments where it may be used multiple times.

author: Witold Wasiczko
description: Computes the execution time of the inner middleware and stores the result into the `X-Response-Time` response header.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Adds `Expires` and `max-age` directives of the `Cache-Control` header in the response. It is similar to the apache module [mod_expires](https://httpd.apache.org/docs/current/mod/mod_expires.html). By default uses the same configuration of [h5bp apache configuration](https://github.com/h5bp/server-configs-apache/blob/master/src/web_performance/expires_headers.conf). Useful for static files.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Adds `Expires` and `Cache-Control: max-age` headers to the response.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Allows the usage of [FastRoute](https://github.com/nikic/FastRoute) as a router. It requires an instance of FastRoute `Dispatcher`.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Allows the usage of [FastRoute](https://github.com/nikic/FastRoute) as a router. It requires an instance of FastRoute `Dispatcher`.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Middleware to read responses from files. It uses [Flysystem](http://flysystem.thephpleague.com/) as filesystem handler, so you can use not only a local directories, but also any other adapter like [ftp](http://flysystem.thephpleague.com/adapter/ftp/), [sftp](http://flysystem.thephpleague.com/adapter/sftp/), [dropbox](http://flysystem.thephpleague.com/adapter/dropbox/), etc...

author: Oscar Otero
description: Middleware to save response content into a file. It uses [Flysystem](http://flysystem.thephpleague.com/) as filesystem handler, so you can use not only a local directories, but also any other adapter like [ftp](http://flysystem.thephpleague.com/adapter/ftp/), [sftp](http://flysystem.thephpleague.com/adapter/sftp/), [dropbox](http://flysystem.thephpleague.com/adapter/dropbox/), etc...

author: Oscar Otero
description: Uses [M6Web/Firewall](https://github.com/M6Web/Firewall) to provide an IP filtering. This middleware depends of `ClientIp` middleware to extract the ip(s) from the headers. See the [allowes ip formats](https://github.com/M6Web/Firewall#entries-formats) for trusted/untrusted options.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Uses [M6Web/Firewall](https://github.com/M6Web/Firewall) to provide an IP filtering. See the [allowes ip formats](https://github.com/M6Web/Firewall#entries-formats) for trusted/untrusted options.

author: Relay Php team
description: Parses payloads of requests that hanve `application/x-www-form-urleconded` as content type, and makes the parameters available in subsequest middleware.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Uses [willdurand/Negotiation](https://github.com/willdurand/Negotiation) to detect and negotiate the format of the document using the url extension and/or the `Accept` Http header. It also adds the `Content-Type` header to the response if it is missing.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Simple spam protection based on injecting a hidden input in all post forms with the current timestamp. On submit, the form checks the time value. If it is older than (for example) 3 seconds ago, assumes it's a bot, so returns a 403 response. You can configure a max number of seconds before the form expires.

author: Witold Wasiczko
description: Recognizes location by IP from `ServerRequest` attributes and sets a `geoip_address_collection` attribute with a `\Geocoder\Model\AddressCollection` instance.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Uses [Geocoder](https://github.com/geocoder-php/Geocoder) library to geolocate the client using the ip. This middleware depends on `ClientIp` middleware (to extract the ip(s) from the headers). It needs to receive a Geocoder `Geocoder` instance.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Middleware to geolocate the client using the ip address and [Geocoder](https://github.com/geocoder-php/Geocoder) and save the result as a request attribute.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Injects the Google Analytics code in all `Html` pages.

author: Michael Mayer
description: This middleware is part of a set of middleware to handle CSRF. This one is used as a guard, to check if the request has an attibute set which denotes that it passed CSRF validation.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Uses gzip functions to compress the response body, inserting also the `Content-Encoding` header.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Implements a honeypot spam prevention. This technique is based on creating a input field that should be invisible and left empty by real users but filled by most spam bots. The middleware scans the html code and inserts this input in all post forms and checks in the incoming requests whether this value exists and is empty (is a real user) or doesn't exist or has a value (is a bot) returning a 403 response.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Implements a honeypot spam prevention. This technique is based on creating a input field that should be invisible and left empty by real users but filled by most spam bots. The middleware scans the html code and inserts this input in all post forms and checks in the incoming requests whether this value exists and is empty (is a real user) or doesn't exist or has a value (is a bot) returning a 403 response.

author: Witold Wasiczko
description: Uses a provided `AuthorizationServiceInterface` instance to check if the application should process the request. Otherwise returns a `401` response.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Middleware to implement [Basic access Authentication](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Basic_access_authentication) compliant with [RFC 2617](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2617).

author: Oscar Otero
description: Middleware to implement [Digest access Authentication](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digest_access_authentication) compliant with [RFC 2617](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2617).

author: Slim Team
description: Manages client side cache

author: Leandro Silva
description: This middleware will log requests and responses in compact or full mode. It will include `X-Request-Id` and `X-Response-Time` headers if present.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Returns a redirection to the https scheme if the request uri is http. It also adds the [Strict Transport Security](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTTP_Strict_Transport_Security) header to protect against protocol downgrade attacks and cookie hijacking.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Middleware to redirect to `https` if the request is http and add the [Strict Transport Security](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTTP_Strict_Transport_Security) header to protect against protocol downgrade attacks and cookie hijacking.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Middleware to transform images on demand, allowing resize, crop, rotate and transform to other formats. Uses [imagecow](https://github.com/oscarotero/imagecow) library that can detect and use `Gd` and `Imagick`, and also has support for client hints and different automatic cropping methods.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Uses [imagecow/imagecow](https://github.com/oscarotero/imagecow) to transform images on demand. It can be used to resize, crop, rotate and convert to other formats. It uses the the [imagecow syntax](https://github.com/oscarotero/imagecow#execute-multiple-functions) to define the available sizes. To define the available sizes, you have to assign a filename prefix representing the size, so any requested file with this prefix will be dinamically transformed. It provides also support for [Client hints](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2016/01/leaner-responsive-images-client-hints/) to avoid to serve images larger than needed (currently supported only in Chrome and Opera). You could also save the transformed images in cache, providig a [PSR-6](www.php-fig.org/psr/psr-6) compatible library.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Useful to include old style applications, in which each page has its own php file. This middleware gets the php file, includes it safely, captures the output and the headers and creates a response with the results. If the file does not exits, returns a 404 response (unless continueOnError is true).

author: Mika Tuupola
description: Companion middleware for Instrument. With [Instrument](https://github.com/tuupola/instrument) you can monitor and measure your PHP application performance. It can collect and store metrics such as script execution time and memory usage or time spent in database. You must have access to [InfluxDB](https://influxdata.com/) database to store the data.

author: Relay Php team
description: Deserializes the `JSON` payload of a request object and makes the parameters available in subsequent middleware decorators. It checks the incoming request for a method other than `GET` and for an `application/json` or `application/vnd.api+json` `Content-Type` header. If it finds both of these, it parses the `JSON` and makes it available as the parsed body of the `$request` before passing it and the `$response` to `$next`.

author: Oscar Otero
shortDescription: Middleware to validate `application/json` schema on route basis.
description: Uses [justinrainbow/json-schema](https://github.com/justinrainbow/json-schema) to validate an `application/json` request body using route-matched JSON schemas.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Uses [justinrainbow/json-schema](https://github.com/justinrainbow/json-schema) to validate an `application/json` request body with a JSON schemas.

author: Aurimas Niekis
description: Uses [namshi/jose](https://github.com/namshi/jose) to validate a `jwt` token.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Uses [willdurand/Negotiation](https://github.com/willdurand/Negotiation) to detect and negotiate the client language using the `Accept-Language` header and (optionally) the uri's path. You must provide an array with all available languages.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Allows the usage of [league/route](https://github.com/thephpleague/route) as a middleware. It requires a League `RouteCollection` instance.

author: Witold Wasiczko
description: Provides the possibility to log request and response messages to a provided [PSR-3](http://www.php-fig.org/psr/psr-3/) compliant logger.

author: Witold Wasiczko
description: Returns a response with a `503` status code. It supports `Retry-After` and `Redirect` headers.

author: Prooph team
description: Part of he Prooph ecosystem. Dispatches the message data to the suitable bus system (i.e. command bus, query bus or event bus) depending on message type.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Overrides the request method using the `X-Http-Method-Override` header. This is useful for clients unable to send other methods than `GET` and `POST`.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Overrides the request method using the `X-Http-Method-Override` header. This is useful for clients unable to send other methods than `GET` and `POST`.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Simple (but powerful) [PSR-15](https://github.com/php-fig/fig-standards/blob/master/proposed/http-middleware/middleware.md) middleware dispatcher. It requires a [PSR-7](http://www.php-fig.org/psr/psr-7/) implementation and optionally, a [PSR-11](https://github.com/container-interop/fig-standards/blob/master/proposed/container.md) container implementation.

author: Rasmus Schultz
description: Dead simple [PSR-15](https://github.com/php-fig/fig-standards/blob/master/proposed/http-middleware/middleware.md)/[PSR-7](http://www.php-fig.org/psr/psr-7/) middleware dispatcher. Provides optional integration with a variety of dependency injection containers compliant with [PSR-11](https://github.com/container-interop/fig-standards/blob/master/proposed/container.md).

author: Oscar Otero
description: Uses [mrclay/minify](https://github.com/mrclay/minify) to minify css files.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Uses [mrclay/minify](https://github.com/mrclay/minify) to minify html responses.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Uses [mrclay/minify](https://github.com/mrclay/minify) to minify javascript files.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Uses [mrclay/minify](https://github.com/mrclay/minify) to minify the html, css and js code of the responses.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Middleware using [wildurand/Negotiation](https://github.com/willdurand/Negotiation) to implement content negotiation. Detects the preferred encoding type using the `Accept-Encoding` header and edits the header with this value.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Middleware using [wildurand/Negotiation](https://github.com/willdurand/Negotiation) to implement content negotiation. Detects the preferred language using the `Accept-Language` header or the path prefix and edits the header with this value. A `Content-Language` header is also added to the response if it is missing.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Middleware using [wildurand/Negotiation](https://github.com/willdurand/Negotiation) to implement content negotiation. Detects the preferred mime type using the `Accept` header and the path extension and edits the header with this value. A `Content-Type` header is also added to the response if it is missing.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Parses the body of the request if it is not parsed and the method is `POST `, `PUT` or `DELETE`. It has support for json, csv and url encoded format.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Parses the csv payload of the request if it's not parsed and the method is `POST`, `PUT` or `DELETE`.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Parses the json payload of the request if it's not parsed and the method is `POST`, `PUT` or `DELETE`.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Parses the url-encoded payload of the request if it's not parsed and the method is `POST`, `PUT` or `DELETE`.

author: Glenn Eggleton
description: This middleware checks to see if a user has a permission to access a specific resource. It assumes that the middleware is loaded with all of the routes the system is applied to and that the user's permission table is loaded into the Requests `permission` attribute. It a user attempts to access a resource he is not allowed, an `Exception` is raised.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Initializes a [php session](http://php.net/manual/en/book.session.php) using the request data.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Middleware to start a [php session](http://php.net/manual/en/book.session.php) using the request data and close it after returning the response.

author: Oscar Otero
description: To use the [Piwik](https://piwik.org/) analytics platform. It injects the javascript code just before the `</body>` closing tag.

author: BitExpert AG team
description: This middleware add a [Prophiler](https://prophiler.fabfuel.de/) to the `Response` object.

author: Oscar Otero
shortDescription: Middleware to forward requests and return responses
description: Forwards a request using [Guzzle](http://docs.guzzlephp.org) and returns the received request.

author: Prooph team
description: Part of he Prooph ecosystem. Dispatches the message data to the query bus system. The middleware needs a request attribute to create the appropriare message object.

author: Leandro Silva
description: Middleware to implement a rate limit. The middleware will look for an `X-Api-Key` header as a key and, if not found, it will fallback to the remote IP. Each key has its own limit. This middleware does not validate the Api Key, you should add a middleware before this one to validate it.

author: Nikola Posa
description: Rate limiting middleware designed for API and/or other application endpoints. The package supports creating different rate limiting strategies based on the `RateLimit/RateLimiterInterface` interface. This implementation does rate limiting based on specified number of requests per time window.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Reads the response content from a file. It is the opposite of `SaveResponse`. The option `continueOnError` changes the behaviour of the middleware to continue with the next middleware if the response file is NOT found and returns directly the response if the file is found. This is useful to use as a file based cache, adding a router middleware (or other readResponses) next in the queue.

author: Oscar Otero
description: To use the [google recaptcha](https://github.com/google/recaptcha) library for spam prevention.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Middleware to use [google/recaptcha](https://github.com/google/recaptcha) library for spam prevention. Returns a `403` response if the request is not valid.

author: Glenn Eggleton
description: This middleware helps you guard your application with [Google ReCaptcha](https://github.com/google/recaptcha).

author: SadeghPM
description: This middleware implement server side Google reCAPCHA v2 validation.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Middleware to block referrer spammers using [piwik/referrer-spam-blacklist](https://github.com/piwik/referrer-spam-blacklist). It returns a `403` response if the url host in the Referer header is in the blacklist.

author: Michael Mayer
description: This middleware is part of a set of middlewares to handle CSRF. This one is used to return a `403 Access Forbidden` response.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Renames the request path. This could be useful to rename public paths with a random suffix, for security reasons, or to create pretty urls without using any router. For example to access the path `/static-pages/about-me.php` under the more friendly `/about-me`.

author: Leandro Silva
description: Adds a Request ID header that can be used to trace back requests for logging purposes. It uses [Ramsey\Uuid](https://github.com/ramsey/uuid) library for generating ids.

author: Witold Wasiczko
description: This middleware provides framework-agnostic possibility to generate and add to request/response's header Request ID. It requires a `PhpMiddleware\RequestId\RequestIdProviderFactoryInterface` implementation which must create a new `RequestIdProviderInterface` object.

author: Witold Wasiczko
description: Provides the ability to simulate a request passing the simulated request parameters in the actual request body. It may be useful for testing.

author: Michael Mayer
description: This middleware is part of a set of middlewares to handle CSRF. This one is used for sending CSRF tokens by cookies.

author: Michael Mayer
description: This middleware is part of a set of middlewares to handle CSRF. This one is used for sending CSRF tokens by response headers.

author: Relay Php team
description: It does nothing with the `$request` or `$response`, passing them immediately to `$next`. Afterwards, it takes the returned `$response` and sends it using `header()` and `echo`, and returns the sent `$response`.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Calculates the response time in milliseconds and saves it into the `X-Response-Time` header.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Calculates the response time in milliseconds and saves it into the `X-Response-Time` header.

author: Leandro Silva
description: Calculates the response time and saves it into the `X-Response-Time` header.

author: Rob Allen
description: Middleware that determines the client IP address and stores it as an `ServerRequest` attribute called `ip_address`. It checks the  `X-Forwarded-For`, `X-Forwarded`, `X-Cluster-Client-Ip`, `Client-Ip` headers for the first IP address it can find. If none of the headers exist, or do not have a valid IP address, then the `$_SERVER['REMOTE_ADDR']` is used.

author: Rob Allen
description: Middleware that determines the scheme and host from the `X-Forwarded-Proto` and `X-Forwarded-Host` headers and updates the `Request`'s `Uri` object. You can set a list of proxies that are trusted as the second constructor parameter. If this list is set, then the proxy headers will only be checked if the `REMOTE_ADDR` is in the trusted list.

author: Rob Allen
description: Middleware to start a native Php session.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Disables the search engine robots for non-production environment. Adds automatically the `X-Robots-Tag: noindex, nofollow, noarchive` header in all responses and returns a default body for `/robots.txt` requests.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Disables the search engine robots for non-production environment. Adds automatically the `X-Robots-Tag: noindex, nofollow, noarchive` header in all responses and returns a default body for `/robots.txt` requests.

author: Prasetyo Wicaksono
description: Routing middleware based on [nikic/fast-route](https://github.com/nikic/FastRoute).

author: Oscar Otero
description: Saves the response content into a file if all of the following conditions are met: the method is `GET`, the status code is `200`, the `Cache-Control` header does not contain `no-cache` value and the request has no query parameters. This is useful for caching purposes.

author: Mika Tuupola
description: Implements the [Server-Timing](http://wicg.github.io/server-timing/) header which can be used for displaying server side timing information on Chrome developer console.

author: Marco Pivetta, Jefersson Nathan and Luis Cobucci
description: Enables session usage storing session data inside a session cookie as a JWT token.

author: Relay Php team
description: Normally, PHP will send out headers for you automatically when you call `session_start()`. However, this means the headers are not being sent as part of the response object, and are thus outside your control. This handler puts them back under your control by placing the relevant headers in the response; its behavior is almost identical to the native PHP automatic session headers behavior. For this middleware to work, you must disable the PHP session header management ini settings.

author: Glenn Eggleton
description: This middleware injects your session content into the Request Object.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Useful to display a 503 maintenance page. It requires an handler to decide for which pages to display the 503 page.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Useful to display a 503 maintenance page. It requires an handler to decide for which pages to display the 503 page.

author: Mika Tuupola
description: This middleware implements HTTP Basic Authentication. It is configurable with an array of users usernames and passwords.

author: Adoni Pavlakis
shortDescription: Mock a GET request to be made through the CLI
description: This middlewares enables making a mock GET request through the CLI and enabling the same application entry point on CLI scripts.

author: Mika Tuupola
description: This middleware implements automatic image resizing based on image filename. You can configure the allowed image extensions and cache folder.

author: Mika Tuupola
description: This middleware implements JSON Web Token Authentication. It only parses and authenticates a token when passed via header or cookie. This is useful for example when you want to use JSON Web Tokens as API keys.

author: Michael Mayer
description: Middleware to create a stack of middlewares so that the could be used as a single middleware.

author: Semen Tokarev
description: Middleware to create a stack of middlewares so that the could be used as a single middleware.

author: Zend Framework Team
description: Use this middleware as the outermost (or close to outermost) middleware layer, and use it to intercept PHP errors and exceptions. The functionality of the middleware could be extended via error response generators and listeners.

author: Zend Framework Team
shortDescription: Wraps a callable in a single pass middleware
description: Wraps a callable with a single pass middleware signature in an actual middleware.

author: Zend Framework Team
shortDescription: Wraps a double pass middleware in a single pass middleware
description: Wraps a callable with a double pass middleware signature in a single pass middleware.

author: Zend Framework Team
description: Handles the `404` case, providing a standard response.

author: Zend Framework Team
shortDescription: Inject attributes containing the original request, response, and URI instances
description: This middleware will add `originalRequest`, `originalResponse` and `originalUri` request attributes. These can then be reference later, for tasks such as determining the base path when generating a URI, determining if changes to the response have occurred or providing prototypes for factories.

author: Zend Framework Team
description: This middleware implements a pipeline of middleware, which can be attached using the `pipe()` method. It creates an instance of `Next` internally, invoking it with the provided request and response instances, passing the original request and the returned response to the `$next` argument when complete.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Removes (or adds) the trailing slash of the path. For example, `/post/23/` will be converted to `/post/23`. If the path is `/` it won't be converted. This could be useful for managing router problems.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Middleware to normalize the trailing slash of the uri path. By default removes the slash so, for example, `/post/23/` is converted to `/post/23`. Useful if you have problems with the router.

author: Justinas Rakašis
description: Determines the client user agent and stores it as a `ServerRequest` attribute.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Uses [ramsey/uuid](https://github.com/ramsey/uuid) to generate an Uuid (Universally Unique Identifiers) for each request (compatible with [RFC 4122](http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4122) versions 1, 3, 4 and 5). It could be useful for debugging purposes.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Middleware to generate an UUID (Universally Unique Identifiers) and save it in the `X-Uuid` header of the request and response. Useful for debugging purposes. The UUID generated is compatible with [RFC 4122](http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4122) version 4 using [ramsey/uuid](https://github.com/ramsey/uuid) for that.

author: Aurimas Niekis
shortDescription: Middleware to use a custom `json` content type header
description: Replaces the `application-json` value of the `Content-Type` header with a vendor custom value.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Allows the usage of [Whoops](https://github.com/filp/whoops) as error handler. It requires a Whoops `Run` instance as a dependency.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Allows the usage of [Whoops](https://github.com/filp/whoops) as error handler. It requires a Whoops `Run` instance as a dependency.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Adds or removes the `www` subdomain in the host uri and, optionally, returns a redirect response. It will not change the uri if it is `localhost`, an ip based host or if the host already have a subdomain.

author: Oscar Otero
description: Adds or removes the `www` subdomain in the host uri and, optionally, returns a redirect response. It will not change the uri if it is `localhost`, an ip based host or if the host already have a subdomain.
